Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

>>26257464
Year 1:
1: Absolutely hard, but you do get a mobile watchtower trailer which is cool and will be needed here. Vehicles given here aren't great so this is definitely one of the last areas to do in the entire DLC lineup when you're better equipped.
2: Vehicles are a gimmick used only largely on this map, but the difficulty is interesting at least with mud/snow mix. I like the verticality of this one.
3: One of the better areas for starters because the oversized trailers can actually be used rather well here. Hope you like mud, but probably next to Alaska in ease. Vehicles here are kind of nice.
4: It's Season 1 but with even more dickheaded design. You do get the best superheavy truck on this level to compensate. Just like 1, I wouldn't come here until you have better equipment.
Year 2:
5: Distilled bullshit starting off. Not as bad once you get the tempo down and get out some decent ground clearance trucks. Trucks unlocked here are okay but nothing to note since you probably have a decent lineup by now.
6: Gimmick is a Hardcore-Lite mode until you progress far enough, in which is just becomes like 2 but easier. Trucks you get here are good but unlock way too damn late.
7: Easily and without a doubt the single worst DLC of the game. Not really tough but extremely lacking content and feels like recycled assets from the Dakar game they (then) recently released. Vehicles really only work on this level and nowhere else in the game, and the whole level is so short with content you could 100% it in a session or two.
8: Tries to redeem the failure of 7 by adding four massive areas to drive around in. Might be easier than 3 in terms of difficulty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26257785
Premiums:
Navistar 5000-MV: It's just the BOAR from 3, but with slightly worse fuel usage and a military look. This was the preorder DLC which dominates Michigan/early game, but very quickly falls off later.
Brigadier: This is just a slightly fancier version of the GMC truck you get from Michigan. It's an okay performing truck but I wouldn't really say it's mandatory or good except if you want to be a completionist.
Chevy Apache: Similar to the Navistar in that it's like a truck you will get later on (YAR in vanilla) unlocked earlier to dominate early game.
CAT CT681/International HX 520: Arguably the best premiums because of being free, they make excellent support trucks. The CAT 681 when upgraded with a good engine and highrange is one of the best trucks in the game for moving quick.
Western Star 49X: A big fat heavy truck that is only really good for pulling large trailers. Will fuck you if you play Hard mode due to the extra maintenance costs.
Tatra 813/805: You'll get this one automatically on buying the Year 1 pass. 805 makes for a very good heavy offroad truck until you get a larger toolset to use. Personally used it for the GOAT Zikz on Season 4.
Jeeps: Mediocre scouts with not much ability, even to haul trailers. Might be fine in light dirt but are very useless to do anything serious.
Crocodile: Makes for a good resupply truck, one of the better premiums actually. Similar to the trucks you unlock in Season 1 but without the suspension problems.
Western Star Pack: Aesthetically a cool pack with the 57X, but by this point you've seen this trucks already and have trucks with much better performance considering these are highway/light vocational trucks.
Hercules: Like the Apache, but without the ability to pull a trailer.

My quick and dirty unofficial guide to starting off:
>Fuck off out of Michigan, head to Russia to beeline it to the Tayga repair mission
>Repair the Tayga, take it back with you to Alaska
>Run some missions in Alaska until you're at a decent enough money/level to start affording better tires
>You want to get off highways ASAP, it'll become a lot easier to deal with thick mud after that point
>In (almost) every case, I is better on road, III better on dirt, and II in mud, so swap to IIs if you get stuck often
>Almost all chains are identical, performing like All-Terrains in mud and Offroads in dirt
>You can force a transmission to act as a semi-automatic by clicking the gear shift to force the transmission to shift for you (mandatory for some of Season 7)
>Pacific trucks despite the lack of AWD have some of the best traction values for tires, best tires in the game are on the heavy Russian scout in the final vanilla region
>Highrange transmission does reduce fuel usage slightly even when idling, while Advanced transmission increases it
>If you have yet to complete the Season 4 DLC or know someone who needs to complete the Season 4 DLC, see if you can find a party trying to unlock the Zikz as it along with the Tayga will carry you through the hardest parts of the game

>>26251972
There's nothing stopping them working in heavy vehicles aside from max axle weight limits. They can tow fine, they make more torque than a diesel (literally they have to be derated to what their differentials can handle) and their only real drawback is the weight of batteries. If we could have 10,500kg dual axles (what the manufacturer rates them at) rather than 8500kg (their legal max on road) there would be no trouble building EV trucks with 500+km range. It's just fuckin dumb axle weight laws holding them back.

I hate EVs as much as the next guy, but there's no denying that emissions standards are making diesel engines thirsty, expensive and unreliable. Unless emissions standards are rolled back, diesel will be dead (outside of special applications) in 15 years in favor of BEV and FCEV trucks.

For context I've been a diesel mechanic 14 years and an EV mechanic 5 years so I do know a bit more than your average shitposter.

Except that the other advantage of at least one type of those more dense cells is their extreme safety. A bunch of other companies have similar time frames for their solid state cells. Low volume heavy machinery will probably be an obvious early application for them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26257682
>which is what ?200,000wh/kg?
Gasoline is ~12,000 Wh/kg.

>Batteries need to get to the same energy density as current fuels plain and simple
No, no they don't. They just need to get to the same kWh output potential for the powertrain for about the same mass as the whole powertrain.

So if you have a 30 gallon fuel tank that's 80kg for ~1 MWh of stored energy, but if the engine to convert that into work is only 25% efficient you only get 250kWh of work out of it. The other downside for ICE is that depending on the power output and duty cycle of the engine, it and its ancillaries to turn that into useful work and support the engines operation might be a pretty significant mass.

So to use an example that's fresh in my mind a flow battery might have a 60 gallon tank storing ~333kWh, but then the energy output is 80% efficient which yields a similar potential energy output of ~260kWh.
Yes it is double the tank size for 1/3 the stored energy, but the rest of the powertrain can be substantially more compact and simple delivering similar results for same mass.

Flow batteries also have the advantage that the depleted fluid that flows through the pack gets drained out of the battery to be recharged, and charged up fluid can get loaded in about as fast as a fuel tank could be filled.
They just aren't great for personal vehicles because packaging that much volume into a car and rigging up a way to drain the old fluid isn't going to really be something the average joe can do, but it could totally work for more niche applications like heavy machinery or tractors, or race cars.

Not that suburbs generally shouldn't exist, just car-dependent suburbs aren't a good use of land.
Ideally a suburb is like a small town where everything is easy walking / biking distance of a 'downtown' area, and that central hub then links into transit.
Within a block of that central hub there might be duplexes, row houses, 4 plexes, but a block or two beyond that you get single family homes on a grid.

Pre-war 'Streetcar' Suburbs are pretty comfy, but that style of traditional development isn't happening in the US anymore. Its what Strong Town advocates a return to.

The L15B has poor engine oiling, tiny crankshaft with poor rod to stroke ratios which prevent the engine from wanting to rev. The rods are weak and bend or shatter above 250whp. They also have tiny rod bolts which are smaller than an average 10mm oil pan nut. This causes the bolts to fail under stress lunching the engine. The head bolts are undersized which cause head gasket problems. Everything about the engine is designed to be as cheap as possible and to save money on gas, not make power. The only people who defend them do it because they own a car with one in it.

posts.name: Sage
posts.com:
>>26242193
They won't be making that much power for very long. Theres a video on YouTube that shows some differences between L15 parts and other honda engines like K20,D16 etc. The l15 crankshaft is about 2/3rds the size of a d16 crankshaft and has tiny balancers and small journals. The rods are much smaller than a k20 and the rod bolts are 3 sizes smaller. The oil galley grooves on the block mains are small and on the center main all oil pressure comes from a single pinhole. No crank girdle to be found. The oil pump gears apparently shatter with increased power or can score and lose oil pressure. The torque to yield head bolts are of a lower quality metal then the K series ones.

This isn't a case of "new engine bad", the l15b is a cost cutting economy engine Honda threw in its Civic SI to save costs and there aren't alot of safety margins built into it once you exceed stock output.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26258058
Vibration. There's quite a lot of mass moving back and forth and in an I4 not all forces compensate or cancel each other out, so it would basically shake itself to pieces if you tried to rev it too hard.
An I6, boxer-6, crossplane V8 or V12 can basically be made as large as you want because the forces inside them do balance out very well.

Actual wrenching thread

I got a Suzuki Kei Works here in Japan, and the A/C isn't working.
First I found that the O-rings for the expansion valve and the evaporator was leaking, so I took that out, vacuumed and charged the system.
Now the I'm seeing dye around the compressor, and (maybe) also the entry port for the condenser, if so another O-ring...
But my question is really just: how common is it for new leaks to show up after fixing one in an ac system.

95% chance this thread is useless because /o/tists aare all wrenchlet busriders

I guess if one o-ring is degraded to the point of failure, it's not unreasonable to assume that another o-ring of the same age and material is also degraded

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A/C system leaks are just about guaranteed if the system hasn't been used in a while, or if it has never been serviced. Just about every O-ring and seal will dry out, shrink, crack etc. The gas runs at pretty high pressures too so the seals need to be in perfect condition.

Today I replaced both the rear wheel bearings in my wagon. Last week I fabricated a special tool for loosening the ring nut holding the bearing into the housing. Tomorrow I'll probably re-route some wiring to add another relay to the engine cooling fans circuit.

i've got the 1.9 JTDm version, had it for 1.5 years now, so far the only real problems is the shitty m32 transmission whining, but from what i've read and heard, thats where it basically stops(fuck you opel), rust on the front and rear subframe and rust on the rear suspension components, one of my front springs just snapped out of nowhere while it was parked for 2 weeks(i have the Ti trim so the sport springs are kinda pricey), the rubber pipe after the intercooler broke, and theres kinda a bit of oil at the turbo and right after it, If you cant stand bumps on the road i'd go for the normal trims since they are way softer than the Ti, but other than that i dont think i've had any super serious issues with it so far, its actually been pretty reliable.

If you want to buy one just dont go with a JTS engine, they are horrible, shit power and shit reliability, especially the 3.2 V6 that has 20L/100km fuel consumption...

>>26257305
Got to remember that the 2 litre petrol in the MK3 Golf GTI only made 115hp and 150hp in the 16v version. In the MK4 Golf GTI with the N/A 2 litre petrol it only made 115hp. The N/A 1.8 litre 20v made 125hp. The Ford Focus Zetec with the 2 litre petrol of the same era only made 130hp as well. The Focus ST170 with the 2 litre petrol was 170, which was the same as the JDM market 323. The Clio 172 was... 172hp with a 2 litre. The Clio 182 was... 182hp with a 2 litre. But the Clio RenaultSport and ST170 were the top of the food chain hot hatches (the ST170 was touched by Cosworth). We didn't even get the 170hp version of the 323 in the UK. And normally the Japs will send us the hot shit and get frustrated when we want more power. The MG ZS was making 180 out of a 2.5 litre V6. The MG ZR with the 1.8 VVC was making 160. The Proton Satria GTi (a mates brother had one of these) which used a 1.8 4G93 was touched by Lotus and made about 140hp.

At the time manufacturers were beginning turbo to make high horse power more easily. The 1st gen Focus RS was tubro'd and made 210ish hp. The 1.8T 20v from VAG made 180. The 2 litre 16v in the Fiat Coupe made 180. The 20v made 220.

TL;DR = 130hp from an N/A 2 litre at the end of the 90s / early 00s wasn't actually that bad. If you wanted more you needed the likes of Cosworth or RenaultSport to breath on your motor. Or MazdaSpeed. Which the Japs did for their own shit, just never exported it.

>>26241426
yeah. took a day or two to nail the basics down. lots of stalling at lights and waving to the driver behind me kek. At one point while learning I was starting to regret swapping to a manual because I kept feeling like shit holding up everyone behind me.
one bro in a hilux must've put two and two together because he waved back three times in a sort of 'it's cool mate shit happens'
But there was no way I was going to put the auto back lol so I just kept at it. Once i realised i could increase the margin before the engine stalled by just keeping the revs at 1500-2000 rpm and slowly releasing the clutch at the same time, i think that was the moment where another anon in a recent thread described learning to drive manual as
>you keep practising until one day it randomly clicks and you never unlearn how to drive a manual ever again
i did about 2000 km in the past week or so just driving everywhere and nowhere and having an absolute blast. People kept telling me that manuals will suck in stop start traffic but honestly I didn't find it too bad. Just figure out the pace at which you can just crawl along.
Now it's a matter of refining the technique. Have gotten better and better at revmatching, but it'll be a while yet until i can do the manual racing memes like heel toe shifting and all that
pic related was when I initially installed the pedals. looked wonky as you can see, thankfully my work had a hydraulic metal bender which allowed me to get the pedals at the perfect position

give yourself about a week if you've never done it before, are doing it solo, and are relying on a floor jack instead of a gearbox jack

on a side note, the speedo no longer works because the little spring clip (pic related) that holds the speedo drive gear in place on the output shaft, has lost tension after 20 or so odd years of doing its thing. so i have to drop the gearbox again to replace it because it requires taking off the back half of the tranny. Once parts arrive, I'm going to go to a DIY garage because it's so much easier when you have an actual tranny jack. I've been gauging my speed with the tacho though. Really I just like to have everything working. While I'm at it I also have to replace the output shaft seal and revert back to the stock mk3 supra shifter retainer, because the sc300 one i used is a bit too far back. Anyone need it? I can sell the both the retainer and the shift lever arm

posts.com: the stock speaker on the drivers side of my 6th gen celica is starting to distort at medium volume, thinking of replacing it with an aftermarket. Found a good adapter already, but not sure what speaker brand I should put in? needs to be 6.5 inch 400 watt. I don't plan on adding an amp/sub addon, car is too rattly for it to have any serious sound system mods.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26248038
check the oem speaker impedance, iirc nips all use 4 ohm impedance speakers. should be on the back of the speaker itself, where the magnet is. if you install a different impedance speaker it'll be distorted.
If using with factory head unit, look for speakers with a high sensitivity. around 89 db is fine, but higher is always better. watts rms doesn't need to be too high with stock head units too.
I think toyota generally uses 5.25 inch speakers in the door, but take it out and confirm. And also confirm if it's a component or coax speaker, then pick from there.
Alternatively crutchfield has a speaker selector where you can pick what car you have and it'll give you options that fit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26248548
Thanks. Impedance totally slipped my mind, Just checked and yeah they are 4ohm. I'm going by the size the adapter wants the speaker, since it was made for that model.
I'm thinking of replacing the head unit in the future (and even then, just for android auto, not for better amplification) but for now i'll stick with stock. Found a 400w 4ohm 6.5" coax 96dB speaker - Cerwin Vega V465, i'll install that. Thanks

>>26252809
Many of the first gen components are no longer in production, even consumables like the drive shaft carrier bearing assembly which has a unique rubber donut used only on the Century can't be bought anymore. Places like Nengun will list all the components but oftentimes the parts are NLA. I did find a place that might produce the rubber necessary just gotta contact them once I pull it off the car.

I can absolutely believe paying out the ass for an axel. What used parts you can find aren't usually that expensive but the freight is going to be killer. If you can snag one at 15 years old you're in much better condition than most of us in the US with 25+ year old ones. I can tell you at least the first gen century is well made and reliable and mine has over 400k km on the clock which is very unusual for a literal limousine. I imagine the second gen should be as reliable.

>>26255373
there's a speeding sweet spot
>70-75 in a 65
>65-70 in a 55
>50-60 in a 45
>40-45 in a 35
>30 in a 25
Any more than that, and you're actually becoming a danger to people, unless you're in an actual performance vehicle.
usually the worst offenders are:
>broccoli top zoomers in dad's beemer who will inevitably donate their radiator to the nearest jersey barrier
>black people fist-pumping to rap while talking on the cell phone
>sportbike fags preparing for their metamorphosis into a piece of modern art
>any driver from Maryland (see group 2)
Any less than that and you fall into one of two categories:
>fundamentally inept drivers who think that going the speed limit exempts them from paying attention or having the skill to control their vehicle in traffic (asian women and old people, any lane other than the right lane)
>folks who've had a bad day and just want to get home (in the right lane)

The problem with speeding is that to actually make up any time, you need to speed more the higher the speed limit is.
Doing 50 in a 25 will get you in (ideally) half the time
doing 80 in a 65 will only get you there like 20% faster
so doing 15-20 over really only makes sense in low-speed limit areas because you're only gaining like 3-4 minutes on the highway while risking a potential reckless charge

>>26254078
The normie adage is that "Flying is remarkably safer than driving per mile".
That's true, but it's true for all flights, which are overwhelmingly on commercial carriers. The General Aviation (and below, i.e. experimentals, sport, ultralight, glide, etc) classes have a record more akin to motorcycles, or *worse*. However, one counterpoint is that GA *includes* things like aerobatic aircraft and some other risky shit. Suffice it to say, you need to keep your head about you like you're hooning around like a fool on a crotch rocket, because the stats put you somewhere in that ballpark of danger. Is most of it driven by complacent pilots who don't watch for other aircraft and collide and fucking die, because in a collision in the air, you don't get to dump the bike and skid, and you instead drop to the fucking Earth? Probably. But, familiarity always breeds complacency. And just like in biker circles, they say "well y'know, I trust MYSELF, but, I don't trust OTHER people on the road!", you need to always be watching and assuming stupidest intentions. Keep your eyes outside the cockpit fren.
-t. working on a PPL in 172s

Could be a number of things but the most likley is that water (which is a byproduct from combustion) is precipitating in your cold exhaust pipe, and that when your exhaust heats up (as the engine does) it makes it out the end of the exhaust still in gaseous form. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26248477
We'll start with the most serious issue: The cracked block.
If it was cracked externally, you'd doubtless have found the leak by now.
If it was cracked internally, you definitely notice symptoms such as fluid contamination. Given you state that's not happening, nor is it building too much pressure, then I'm optimistic you can rule out the block/head/head gasket.

Likewise, if the EGR manifold/cooler assembly has started leaking, you'll be able to tell as exhaust gases would be present to some degree in the coolant, darkening it. If not darkening it, then a sniffer test would detect the presence of coolant. They're a simple kit to buy and use.

Failing that, we're left with the wet intake manifold as the most likely cause of the three you've listed.
Testing it (and the EGR manifold, if it comes to it) is easy - if a little awkward.
Basically block one pipe, and find some way to fit a tyre valve to the other. Inflate to 20 psi, use water/suds to make sure your pipe block/valve arent leaking and observe any pressure drop. Over, say, half an hour. A leaking component will have lost it's pressure.

Or you can remove the components completely, then submerge them like a tyre tube and look for bubbles.

Also, take out your spark plugs. If it's the EGR or the intake, then ALL the plugs should have signs of burning coolant.
If only one or two plugs have it, then it's an engine issue.
The coolant-fouled plug is on the right

posts.com: Does it help or hinder tire alignment that electric cars have 4 independent motors instead of one motor/driveshaft powering all the wheels? Debating with a friend, one of us thinks it's easier because each wheel can have sensors and adjust alignment as needed, one of us thinks it's worse because there's nothing mechanical keeping the system in sync.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26251509
>Electronic on-the-fly wheel alignment adjustment
Jesus I can't think of anything more horrifying. Luckily, I don't ever see that happening on mass market vehicles; the alignment will be held rigid by threaded bolt members or bolted eccentric cam washers.
Having four wheel motors won't have any effect on that setup because the motors will be "inboard", meaning they drive the wheels from inside the sprung mass of the vehicle, dividing the torsional stress of acceleration between the motor's mounts, the driveshaft and the suspension mounts.

Even if the motors were all hub mounted, the only thing it would do is increase the stress of acceleration on the suspension mounts, making them more likely to wear earlier, which could *then* impact alignment.
Stronger components/bushings would negate that, however.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26250095
On the 122, it's not really so simple. There's a manifold block that bolts to the side of the head, and this block is where the hot coolant flows out of the engine from and into the radiator. The thermostat housing bolts onto it, and it has the ports for the coolant level and the coolant temperature sensors. And also the EGR gasses flow through it (it does have vacuum modulated EGR). But, closing off the EGR valve would only prevent the EGR gasses from continuing into the intake, it would NOT prevent the EGR gasses from entering this manifold and potentially entering the coolant loop (if there is a crack here). So "ripping out the EGR" would involve at minimum some kind of blockoff plate custom made for the shape of this manifold, and the shadetree tools I've got don't extend to a mill. But believe me, I've thought about it.

1/5
>Back in 1987, Alois Ruf stunned car enthusiasts all over the world with the sheer speed of his CTR Yellow Bird. Seemingly from nowhere, the underdog blew away the fastest factory supercars in the famous Road & Track Top Speed shootout at VW’s Ehra Lessien test track, where it was clocked at 211.5mph or 338.4km/h.
>However, the real speed event that catapulted Ruf to worldwide fame was the video he commissioned entitled “Fascination Nurburgring Ruf CTR Yellow Bird”. In an epic piece of driving, Auto Motor & Sport test driver, Stefan Roser, pedalled the CTR round the world’s most challenging race track sideways through every bend, and sometimes sideways along the straight bits too.
>I have known Stefan for over 20 years, but in all that time we never really talked about his history in the business. So a few months ago, I asked him if he could meet me at Ruf Automobile to be re-united with his steed and do some reminiscing.
>It sounds like he is joking when he tells you this, but Stefan really did learn his car control craft in an old 30hp VW Beetle on ice and snow when he was 18. “As it is also rear-engined, the 911 handles very much the same only it is far more powerful,” he said with a totally straight face.
>“I had read about such driving when I was in school in the early 1960s, and bought books on rally driving and read about the so-called Scandinavian style,” he explained.
>“When I got my driving licence I started to try out these techniques in deserted car parks in Stuttgart during the winter months. Of course I had to do this at night when there was nobody around or I would have been in trouble with the police. It was a lot of fun!”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26258292
2/5
>“At the time some of my friends had the new Mini Cooper, which had 70hp and front-wheel-drive,” Stefan continued. “The car handled incredibly well and I simply could not follow them on a twisty road or even down the straights. But on snow and driven the Scandinavian way, the Beetle had even better traction than the Mini, and on snow tyres it would happily chug up hills on its mere 30hp.”
>Stefan’s next car was a much more serious driving machine, but he had only owned the BMW 1602 for three weeks before it was stolen. “This was really annoying as I had installed bucket seats and a Momo steering wheel, and I suspect that it was stolen for those parts,” he said. “With 85hp to play with, I could do on dry roads what the Beetle did in the snow.”
>The BMW’s replacement was a Porsche 914, which Stefan modified with a 200hp 2.3 litre 911 race motor fed by two big Weber carburettors with no air filters, and factory S camshafts for improved driveability and reliability.
This car also had uprated torsion bars, a limited slip differential and lightweight interior, and was as fast as the more powerful but heavier 911 Carrera RS 2.7. “It weighed under 950kg with a full fuel tank, and was a really amazing car that delivered a full-on race car feeling,” said Stefan fondly reminiscing.

>“At this point I started my first year at the university in Esslingen studying mechanical engineering, but I clearly could not turn up in the Porsche, so I sold it and bought an Innocenti Mini Cooper, which had a 64hp 1,275cc motor.
>However, Stefan soon got bored of the theoretical side of his course and quit to join Auto Motor Sport magazine as a test driver. This came about through a sailing trip on Lake Konstanz with a friend who worked for AMS. “My friend had a 246GT Dino on test and I was running in convoy with my Mini,” Stefan recalled. His friend in the Dino could not keep up on the twisty roads, and when they arrived, he jumped out and said, “We need you at Auto Motor Sport!”
>And so Stefan changed careers overnight and never looked back. That was in 1976, and he was a senior test driver at AMS until he took early retirement for health reasons in 2009.
>The car that Stefan will always be associated with is the Ruf CTR Yellow Bird. The video he made for Ruf, driving the car on the Nurburgring, is a seminal work of automotive art that later on, when the internet was invented, went viral worldwide as a must see piece of automotive folklore.
>Stefan picked up the story from there. “I first drove the Yellow Bird in 1987,” he recalled. “In the months before this I saw it being built and was sceptical because the speeds that Alois was talking about were just so far greater than any production supercar at the time, and were only possible using the tyres from the Porsche 959.”
>“I remember the first time I drove the CTR in winter conditions,” he continued. “It was very cold and the autobahn was always wet. I teased the car up towards 300km/h, which was crazy if you think about it now, especially on 1980s rubber. The feeling I had was a cross between fascination and downright terror, but I was young, and it did not seem that crazy at the time.”

4/5
>“The idea for the Nurburgring drive actually came out of the TÜV certification tests that Ruf had to complete to get the CTR approved for German road use,” Stefan explained.
>“The CTR had to do 2,500km on the track, which gave me the chance to drive it properly under controlled conditions. The car was simply incredible and when I had completed the first lap, our development engineer, Joe Huber, who was on the stopwatch, went absolutely crazy. He could not believe how fast the car was, and I was still warming up!”
>“I started to really extend the car and was drifting it through the corners, but then cooled it down on the straight so as not to upset the Nurburgring staff who generally did not approve of that kind of driving on their track.”
>Stefan explained that the idea for the video came out of that test drive, and the more dynamic and showy I could make it, the better. “This was easy as the CTR handles so well, and has more than enough power to break traction at will. It was simply a matter of being careful to manage tyre wear as smoking rubber for a complete lap of the ‘Ring was not exactly what Dunlop had in mind.”
>“We also realised that not many people outside of Germany knew about the Nurburgring, so highlighting this most demanding of race tracks was just as important to our production. The combination of special car and special track is what makes this video so special.”
>When asked what he considers to be the best cars he has ever driven, Stefan’s answer comes as a surprise. Despite having driven some of the fastest and most expensive cars in the world during his tenure at Germany’s most influential motoring magazine, Stefan says “VW Golf,” with no hesitation.
>“I like all of the Golf generations apart from the Mk 3, which had serious quality issues compared to the Mk 2 before it and the Mk 4 afterwards,” he says, and especially the Mk 1 GTI, which is a near perfect all round car.”

>On supercars, Stefan considers the Ferrari F430 Scuderia to be a good used buy today. “But I would not buy one because of the silly maintenance costs,” he says.
>So what cars does Mr. Opposite Lock, as he is affectionately known, have in his own garage? “I have Audi A6 3.0 TDI Quattro for the winter, and a Land Rover Defender 110 TD5 for the summer because it is fascinating to drive and you need to work at it even at 80km/h,” he said.
>Stefan’s third ‘car’ is a 1986 Unimog cabriolet. “This is my Bigfoot,” he explained, “and as I live at the foot of the mountains about 70km south of Pfaffenhausen, it is fitted with a snow plough to clear my driveway in winter.”
>And now for the serious cars. Stefan owns not one, but two examples of an original, matching numbers 911 Carrera RS 2.7 Touring. The first was his father’s dark blue car, bought new in 1973, and which now has 190,000 km on the clock.
>The second RS has done 170,000 km and was acquired as a restoration project a few years ago when the values were starting to rise but were nowhere near the stratospheric levels they are today.
>“It was painted white when I got it, but was originally tangerine, and will be returned to its original hue in the course of restoration at Ruf,” said Stefan. “The two cars are just 50 chassis numbers apart – 1330 and 1380 – so they were probably built in the same week.”
>Interestingly, Stefan worked for Porsche as an apprentice at Zuffenhausen and Weissach the early ‘70s, spending time on the Carrera RS 2.7 production line. So his literal and emotional connection to this iconic 911 model goes much deeper than just through ownership.
>He may be officially ‘retired’ now, but Stefan Roser is one of the most hard-core petrolheads I have ever met. Most days, you will find him in his barn, working on his cars. “I walk a little as my doctor says I should,” he told me. “But I much prefer driving!”

>>26255765
yeah i have a 2001 EX and it's fucking great. bought it for $4k with 180k miles on the motor, currently at 256k miles, still runs like a champ.
i haven't done any true off-roading in it, but i live in Oregon and do a ton of hiking in the national and state forests. the forest roads are hella rutted and filled with potholes and you're constantly dodging downed logs, and the CR-V performs like a champ.

>>26255786
re: the salt rust. yeah it can be a problem. i bought my 2001 CR-V in Illinois, and it had spent its life in Illinois and Colorado before I bought it, both states that use a lot of salt in the winter. here in Oregon, every mechanic i take the car to comments on the rust. they immediately peg me for a Midwesterner.
everything on my car is rusty. wheel wells, rear quarter panels, the underside. but it's all surface rust, i haven't had any structural issues. the only rust-related issue i had was a couple years ago when a couple of the brake lines rusted through and i started leaking brake fluid. i got it repaired with some compression fittings. apparently the brake lines are a common spot to get bad rust because they're in a little enclosed area where the salt can accumulate. so that's something to watch out for.

>>26256080
To get up the icy driveway during winter, it was necessary to carry speed and basically 4 wheel drift around all the curves. It was straightforward in a first generation-- easy to rotate (on ice) and pretty much goes where you point it. As I remember, the second generations would resist rotation, so they would plow into a turn, and, when you finally got them to start rotating, it would take some skill to avoid oversteering out of the the turn. It has been 10+ years since I lived there, but I used to go up and down that driveway at least once a day, and the first generations definitely did it better.

>>26257962
You're currently paying ~$1k total in interest over the course of the loan. I'm guessing your monthly payment is probably ~$650.

If you refinance for 5 years you'll pay an extra $1k in interest and lower your monthly payment about $200.

If you refinance for 6 years (most common loan term in the industry right now) you pay an extra $2k in interest and lower your monthly payment by about $300.

Do whatever you gotta do. Your rate will double, even with a 740 score you're looking at 5-6% right now. Also if you refi you're going to pay more interest regardless because the term is longer than your current loan.

I'm doing it right, i don't know what you guys are getting upset about.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pennzoil NISMO GT-R invasion at 2001 NISMO FESTIVAL!

2001 was a rad year! It was a rare and unique opportunity to see all the Pennzoil-sponsored NISMO GT500 cars together. And let me tells you: the legendary american oil brand stopped to sponsor one of two NISMO official team chassis in 2000 JGTC season, but returned to 2001 for sponsor the ex-LOCTITE ZEXEL GT-R car, becoming the ‘Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R’ that year. Different from the 1998 R33, and 1999 R34 Pennzoil GT500 champions, and even helping NISMO to win the 2001 season on team standings along with the sister chassis, the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R has been updated to ‘Castrol PITWORK GT-R’ for 2002, losing the yellow livery and the Pennzoil sponsor once again. So yes, it means that the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R is no longer around us.

Another curious fact, , is that the Pennzoil NISMO GT-R BCNR33 and BNR34 pictured here aren’t “original” cars, but replica based on other chassis. Respectively, they are the 1998 ZEXEL SKYLINE and 1999 CALSONIC SKYLINE repainted as Pennzoil-sponsored cars for NISMO’s heritage.

The original Pennzoil BCNR33 has the low-downforce kit and Nicos GT banner and sometimes can be seen appearing in some events, including the NISMO FESTIVAL itself. The original Pennzoil BNR34 however, has been lost. It was upgraded to ‘Castrol NISMO GT-R’ for 2000 JGTC season, but the car crashed in the first round, being replaced by a new bespoke chassis. NISMO took the IMPUL’s BNR34 late that year to replicate the 1999 JGTC GT500 drivers champion.

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26257179
>Are older cars with lower miles a good purchase?
Maybe.

There's a 2004 CR-V AWD in the garage about 20 feet to my right that's been garage kept from day 1 and has about 33K on it. It immediately needed about $1500 worth of maintenance that hadn't been done because it was never driven. Further it has a vibration that's consistent with a driveshaft from about 40 on up. Turns out that the rear diff mount insulators go bad over time and cause vibration to be transmitted to the cabin. That hasn't been fixed yet so I don't know what that'll cost.

Now I got this for free from a grandparent that no longer drives so the expenses aren't a big deal for me but consider if I'd had to pay above retail, or even good sense, and then add these other repairs in. That would make it a poor deal and is also the sort of thing that very low mileage for their year cars tend to do. Ideally you want low, but not astoundingly low, mileage on a well-cared-for car for the best chance of success.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26257179
Owned one in this exact color, absolutely rock solid for 400k miles with regular maintenance. I sold mine at 200k and I'm sure it had a lot more left. I'd double check if it's had a timing belt and water pump change, as those are 90k interval requirements and will run an extra $600-1k to do. I wouldn't be scared of purchasing one up to 150k on the clock either as long as it's been maintained, these are tanks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26257257
what year was it and when did you buy it? Just concerned the age will have some unforeseeable parts breaking down soon after I buy it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26257624
It was a 2004 V6 FWD. I didn't drive it too long because I settled on it when I really wanted the 4wd one. The 4wd one is a 50/50 split bias, so it's more desirable than newer highlanders. Age shouldn't be a big deal desu, only issues I had were the thermostat going out at 180k and the power steering making noise because the previous owner had a remanufactured rack and pinion that was probably having issues. You shouldn't have problems with anything major breaking down, let's face it you're buying a toyota.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26257752
**Most** Hondas and Toyotas will run forever with care. If you don't feel like wrenching the repairs on toyotas are usually inexpensive at the shop. Youtube has a million videos you can follow along to for diy repairs so don't get dissuaded by the age.

They did. It costs. Various manufacturers have built aluminium cars since the late 19th century. But they were bespoke and/or low volume coach builds for ladder frames. >>26252718
Audi did with the A8 D2, and the A2. While successive generations of Audi A8 are marketed as Audi Space Frame, it contains less and less aluminium with each generation. Even steel Audis (up to the 2008 recession) are reputable for their corrosion resistance (fully galvanized) IF they are correctly repaired when Karen hits them with her SUV.

Lessons learned with aluminium was:
> You need a space frame chassis, since it's not strong enough for monocoque
> With a space frame you can make the chassis stronger than steel would be
> Aluminium is fucking light, it makes cars light (an a8 d2 with interior delete is around 1500 kg kerb, 1700-1900 kg stock, and we didn't talk carbon, since you can replace all paneling if you have the cash for it, the space frame is responsible for keeping the car together), and it makes fun cars
> Aluminium DOES NOT RUST. Ever.
> Aluminium is a bitch to work with in the plant
> Aluminium is a bitch to repair when dented (cost 10x as much as the steel repair would)
> Aluminium is more expensive than steel, so cheap cars are off the menu

With the current EV craze, you need an aluminium/carbon space frame aerodynamic EV. (BMW one upped this, the i3 was made of fucking carbon 189 miles out of 42 kWh battery)
> the space frame is responsible for holding the batteries
> You can pull the wires inside the frame
> passive crash rating off the charts
> Do a light interior and it will be 2-300 kg lighter than the competitor
> Now you can start derating the engine and deleting batteries while keeping the range

If I had infinite $$$, I would EV swap a D2. Problem is that it could only be done if you have infinite $$$

posts.name: laseranon

The Godfather hearse rolled back into the shop for a hemorrhaging trans leak. Of course, the seal was the one behind the viscous coupling, so I had to drop the trans. Hyrdamatic viscous couplings are sealed to the flywheel with a thin ass gasket and 38 bolts, which has to be the dumbest design I've ever seen. It's back in though.
Thanks for reading my blogpost

posts.name: laseranon
posts.com:
>>26252371
I actually couldn't tell you when they stopped using them, but I know they were developed in 1940, and this hearse is a '52, so they had quite a good run. The rest of the guts of the transmission are actually pretty solid and easy to work on, but I dispise the viscous coupling design. When pulling the motor or the trans, you have to drain 7qts out of the coupling and remove the nearly 40 bolts from the flywheel. And when re-installing it, you have to be absurdly careful to not bump or tear the thin paper torus gasket or you'll get the mother of all leaks since it's under a lot of pressure from the centrifugal force of the fluid spinning in the coupling.

posts.name: laseranon
posts.com:
>>26252611
It's not a torque converter since there is no reduction from the input to the output. It's just a viscous coupling that allows slippage between the front and back for the trans to shift while still being able to transfer power 1:1. There isnt a serperate rotor on the inside like there is in a TC, its just two halves of fins that rotate close to each other. So yeah, its more like a clutch, I suppose. That's not unique to this trans though, I've worked on a few others that have the same thing. Here's one out of a 50s Daimler I did a while back.
I doubt GM invented the concept, but I know they're definitely the first ones who ever used it in a production car.

posts.name: laseranon
posts.com:
>>26253207
A torque converter has a stator and has the ability to multiply torque at the output, sort of like a gear reduction. They're usually around a 2.5:1 reduction. A viscous coupling does not have a stator and can't multiply torque, it's best ratio is 1:1.
Also, >>26253215 is right. A torque converter uses the actual flow and direction of the fluid to transmit torque to the stator fins, whereas a viscous coupling simply uses the shear force of the fluid. I would assume it transmits power less efficiently than a torque converter, but I genuinely don't know.
>>26252978
Maybe, but I dont really think so. A torque converter gives the engine more mechanical advantage, especially if you're engineering a small economy car with a small engine.

>>26251877
>Looks like a pasta, I def saw someone larping as a German car mechanic before
Nah he's right, another german mechanic here.
We do indeed get very much training during the entire apprenticeship.
You work in your company as an apprentice. Twice a week you need to go to trade school (Berufsschule) where they teach you hardcore theory of automotive technology, also maths and stuff like that.
Every few months your class will be sent to the chamber of crafts (Handwerkskammer) for courses which last about a week and each one has a different focus. For example "Diesel injection equipment" or "welding basics".
These courses are held by master craftsmen who work for the chamber and are really good at what they do.

So when youre finished after 3 1/2 years you are indeed a really skilled mechanic. You don't just now practical work but you got a solid theoretical foundation about the entire vehicle engineering, how shit works etc.

If you want more you can become a master craftsman yourself. That needs even more courses at the chamber, costs a fair bit of money. But I'd wager a German master craftsman doesn't know less than guys in other countries who got an engineering degree.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
general repair/diagnostics thread. Post what issues you're currently having with your car(s) or what you're planning on repairing. Give advice and help others out.

I'll start.

If you own mk1 p2 volvos like 1999-2005 s60s, s80s, v70s and etc and you have a bad idle you might want to install new sensors in your throttle body. The italian throttle body installed in the early versions used ancient technology that wear down over time and if you don't want to keep buying new ones for 700 dollars you can convert it with hall-sensors for 100 dollars and some time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26251511
Can you elaborate? My dad has a S70 2.5T that recently started running like shit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26251518
I don't know if the s70 2.5t has these issues. Could have the same throttle body.

Basically
>italian Magneti Marelli etm/throttle body was used in most volvos early 2000s
>they kept breaking after around 150k km
>used an older type of sender that relays data to the car
>with time the sender's components break down and gives wrong data
>throttle body might in reality be 5% open but sensors will give back 2%
>computer compensates and the result is revs going from 1000-700 indefinetly
>results in entire throttle body needing replacement since car will die
>cleaning the etm will not help
>only solution is to buy new original italian etm or replace the sensors with solid state


So if you've looked through everything, pcv system, egr, vacuum leaks and all of that but the issue remains. Look at the throttle body and see if it is Magneti Morelli.

People might say that some of the updated throttle bodies are good, but in every updated version they kept the old sensors and they will fail eventually no matter what.

Here is a link to a kit: https://bjprace.se/bilmodell/volvo/rep-ombyggnadssats-volvo-magnetti-marelli-elspjall/

Site mentions that s70 turbos do use the magneti throttle bodies so worth checking out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26251518
>>26251540

https://youtu.be/cuJ8AJY-3Xo

Here is a video of the install and showcasing the issue.

My s60 is in a really good condition and I noticed the revs going up and down the other week. Instantly realized it was this. If your car does this on the magneti volvos this is 100% the issue.

Third iteration / generation. The MK1 TT was the bubbly one. The MK2 was pic related. OP pic is a MK3. Oh, and the actual term "Mark" as a descriptor / designation comes from the military to describe weapons and vehicle engineering. This is abbreviated to "MK". If something is a MK I it is the first generation. The first tank in WW1 was the British MK I. Little Boy was a MK I atomic weapon. Et cetera.

>>26254081
in many europe countries cars over 2000 cc have a wealth tax, which means that you pay around 2 to 5% of the value of the car for about 10 years, every year, on top of the yearly road tax. This happens regardless if the car costs 10k or 100k, if it has a 2000 cc engine or more, you will pay that tax.
in these countries people are starved of high hp and that the reason they jump on those 1.4, 1.6, or 1.8 engines with turbos which are unreliable as hell, because buying a 3.0 litre NA car with the same hp as an 1.8 litre TSI from VAG costs something like 3k/year in taxes, while the 1.8 litre is less than 300.
in other countries here in eu, you are taxed based on your hp, that's why you see there many cars running some obscure diesels, like 2.2 litre, 1.9 litre, etc, that make 90hp, because it's cheaper on the taxes compared to a gasoline 1.2 TSI engine with 110 hp.
GR yaris is successful due to fitting well in the european car taxing system.

The 1st gens are built better. The 2nd gens have more power.

2nd gens suffer from the tranny fluid mixing with the coolant (radiator failure). So you have to look for that.

The spider gears in front diff are weak, but easily fixed by throwing in an auto locker.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26255048
To add some extra info, I believe the fluid mixing in 2nd gens is only in automatic models but I could be wrong about that, either way it can be solved by just having a separate transmission cooler. And 1st gens still use a VG architecture for the v6, so look into timing belt services. 2nd gens move onto the vq40 and utilize a timing chain

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I wheel in my 2012 Pro-4X. It has a manual transmission. It's only had one issue, and that was an easily replaced crankshaft position sensor (~$60? and 15 mins to swap). I did upgrade the front diff to an M205 out of a Titan, which is much beefier and can handle any power you'll likely throw at it.

With the locking rear diff on the Pro-4X and having put it on 33" tires, it keeps up with Jeep Rubicons pretty easily, and it does have a tighter turning radius than the Jeeps. I've been really happy with mine.

The trans cooler failures is only on automatics, and at this point in time, they've all probably been replaced already.

You gotta abandon the notion of "reliability" and replace it with "is this car cheap to maintain at this 2400 dollar price point.
Basically every car you can get today at the 2400 dollar price point is in its end of life. What you're looking for is a car that you can fix on the cheap regularly. That's why tons of people recommend Ford Crown Vic type cars because Ford made an ungodly number of them because it was sold heavily to governments as fleet vehicles. This made them unbelievably cheap, cheap to run, and they known for going gone multiple hundreds of thousands of miles without critical failures like transmission or engine failure. That doesn't mean it doesn't have problems, it means the car generally was cheap to get into and the parts are so ubiquitous that it doesn't have expensive regularly repairs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I did rear locker, because toyota lsd's are open diff's in disguise. It's a different animal now, not only can it do circle work, but it won't ever do the dreaded rocking horse (drive over rock, spin front left - rear right, go nowhere) again. It'll go places in 2wd that i used to have to lock in for. Oh, and, like above, skids. I'll eventually twin lock, probably, idk, maybe. There's some downsides to twin lock and front locked.
Just keep in mind... you'll forever be driving around it, it's more of a auto unlocker, than an auto locker, in that it's basically a weldie unless the clutch is in, then it ratchets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26251641
This is true, in 4x4 you'll get the same 3x4 result front or rear locked. I just got sick of getting stuck on a banana peel in 2wd, i mean it was bad, you'd have called it a loose diff even if it was an open diff. Raw capability has skyrocketed in 2wd and 4wd with it.
I've got manual locking front hubs, but, not sure i 'want' a front locker yet for two reasons, heavier steering (more sand dunes here than rock crawling) and i don't have rubbers on my drive shafts to absorb torque, so not sure i want to load up the xfer case that hard. Plus, like you i've got a winch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26251649
Yeah here it's steep climbs on loose/rocky surfaces. The front locker pulls you up and over in that situation. In sand I can see the rear locker being better.

I will say though that all of the "you wont be able to steer" posts from people were unfounded. I did preemptively beef up my steering system with an idler arm brace and modified the center link for stability, but steering hasn't been an issue at all. You get more feedback through the wheel but it's not like people were saying it would be. The stock power steering pump has been more than enough to handle it.

There are also people who say "you'll break CVs" but haven't had an issue with that either. I'd say you'd break more CVs running open front because youre spinning a loose wheel very fast and then suddenly it will find traction and shock load the axle. With the locker everything is more measured.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26248083
Blutooth dongle.

It’s kind of annoying because you’re going to have to pay for licenses and download different apps for certain cars, but for a $20 bluetooth module and ~$20 per car license purchases, you can get the functionality of like a $500+ scan tool.

This is from somebody who owns 2 standalone scan tools and recently got one of those Veepeak modules. The $25 Veepeak can send commands to change the damn radio station and my $150 Autel can’t do anything close to that.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26248083
>>26248091
But also the $20 bluetooth module with a free app will give you the function of a ~$50 standalone scan tool. You can still read typical codes and erase stuff. The $15-$25 license for each car (depending on the app, like there’s some good all around apps and some brand specific apps) will get you deep into the car’s computer. Before I bought that Veepeak, I was reading a lot of reviews and those are popular with BMW goys because they can reprogram shit with some Bimmer app and their smartphone.

So can’t really lose. It’s free to check basic codes on a friend’s car, and not that expensive if you have some retarded project where you need to go deep with diagnostics.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26249436
Also, that sounds horrifically slow. You must not know how flat rate pay works. I get paid one hour to diagnose a car regardless of how long it actually takes. The snap on software isn't just for CAN access, it's also the "intelligent diagnostics" that give you immediate access to test procedures, connector pinouts, system function descriptions, real fixes, smart data (watches relevant PIDs and dings when something irregular shows up), etc. That way I generally don't have to dick around on Mitchell/AllData/Identifix etc trying to find what I need, it's all right there while I'm standing next to the car. Also, it sounds like you don't have bidirectional functionality (basically the scan tool can force the car to do certain functions when I want, like commanding the fuel pump relay on or something). A lot of OEM diagnostic trees require this functionality. It's also a lab scope/multimeter, if you didn't catch that.

posts.com:
Vehicle specific cables and software.
OBDLink EX cable. Designed specially for Ford/Mazda vehicles for use with FORScan, and supports standard OBD2 as well.

Worth that investment just to clear the airbag code that doesn't fucking reset when you plug the seat connector back in. All the extra stuff that I haven't investigated yet will make it more than worth it I'm sure.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26248464
>once the demand rises
This gets overplayed. Every gallon of gas burned to drive 25 miles in the average ICE vehicle today took about 6kWh of electricity to get into the fuel tank for that to happen.
6kWh put into a typical 4 mile a kWh BEV today will go 24 miles on that same 6kWh. So if every vehicle on the road was magically a BEV tomorrow, demand would only increase marginally.

With 5 and 6 mile a kWh BEVs coming to market, demand may actually decrease slightly. A 6 mile a kWh BEV would drive 36 miles on the same 6kWh. More efficient BEVs are also more practical for owners to run on their own solar generation with some designs where the solar panels are integrated into the vehicle able to add about their needed daily use when parked out in the sun.

>It is highly unlikely that charging once a week will be enough, especially as the cars gets older.
Even a 70% degraded long range car at the end of its life will still have more range than a short range car. Charging once a week overnight, or a couple of times a week for 1 hour in the middle of the night really just comes down to personal preference and the cost of electricity. Its probably cheaper to charge a couple of times a week for 1 hour, than for a few hours less frequently.

>while charging it overnight is a sound strategy, can you guarantee that that will be enough?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26248544
>How do you figure?
Refineries have electrical use measured in terrawatt hours, more than some whole cities. The pumps that extract oil from the ground, and move it in pipelines also use significant amounts of electricity. Then of course gas stations have to keep their lights on, and they also use electric pumps to move the fuel up into your gas tank.
6kWh is actually the low end of estimates. At the high end BEVs already use less electricity than even really exceptional internal combustion vehicles.

The TLDR is that the switch over to BEVs is probably only going to be a small part of the necessary grid upgrades that will be done over the next 30+ years as old dirty coal is phased out in favor of modern safe and clean Nuclear power.

Yes DC charging has less overhead, but there is still overhead, and a 300 watt panel is about 1/4 the power of a standard outlet.

I think you're confusing watt with watt hour

>>26254616
Indians have given us some cheap yet decent performance lower displacement bikes though. China hasn't. Chinese small displacement bikes are basically bad middleweights with tiny engines. Chinese have some middleweights, which are cheaper than a new Japanese middleweight, but don't have value compared to a tried and true used Japanese middleweight. CFMoto has KTM motors yes, but probably detuned, and it seems, on considerably higher chassis when people mostly buy KTMs for the light weight and high strung motors, not because KTM engine designs are good or reliable.

I'd consider a CFmoto if I needed a middleweight and it had to be new or ADV and I couldn't afford Japanese, but that's about it. For the weight, I'd rather have Japanese. If I had the money, I might grumble about Euro bikes made in Asia, but the premium Euro versions have better suspension and weight than the Japanese, where the Chinese ones tend to be worse. It's the same engine, but I wouldn't buy a KTM for the engine, I'd buy a KTM for the entire package.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26254655
Japanese bikes are too heavy compared to KTM though. A KTM of the same weight class has an engine of the next Japanese weight class up, and tends to have better components. If Japanese could make motorcycles just as light, I'd buy Japanese, but they don't because KTM's engineering has better chassis for the class and lighter engines, at the cost of reliability, several oil filters, 10w60 oil, and short service intervals.

I think anyone thinking CFMoto is good because they drop a KTM engine into a heavier chassis than the Japanese is delusional though. If KTM didn't have the low weight and upgraded chassis, there's no way I'd buy KTM over Japanese. KTM engines are unreliable and overly high maintenance. If CFMoto retunes the engines, they've probably sapped the fun out of the KTM engines too. That just leaves you with a bike that's heavier than a Japanese bike, with unreliable and high maintenance second-quality KTM engines but none of the benefits over a Japanese bike.

posts.sub: You are robbing a major bank. What vehicles are you choosing?
posts.com:
In this scenario you will be robbing a major bank in Manhatten, NYC.This will be divided into stages.

1. Initial robbery: a discreet vehicle to carry a 3 man crew including yourself.

2. First escape vehicle: a vehicle parked across the street from the bank thats fast enough to escape police vehicles but nimble enough to make it through NYC traffic. (you can have multiple if theyre 2 seaters.

3. Vehicle swap for a highway chase: you make it to a major interstate and swap into a more fitting vehicle. which option will you choose? pure speed? a vehicle good for ramming for the inevitable police blockades ahead you will face?

4. your lay low vehicle. a vehicle that goes unnoticed while you escape the country or make it to a small town. are you going full npc with a nissan rogue, or do you want a sleeper in case a rogue hero cop spots you and you need to make another getaway?

5. your celebration vehicle. you did it. you successfully pulled off a heist. what new car are you treating yourself with?

Dirt cheap, high mileage black Town Car
>First escape vehicle:
White Ford Transit Ecoboost/Chevrolet Express V8/duramax done up to look like a full on tradie van (with at least two or three sets of removable magnet company logos on hand), but with a decent quality low profile push bar since you're not getting through heavy traffic without moving people out of the way
